name: Haiti
description: Haiti, the second smallest independent nation in the Americas, is a land of dramatic contrasts – stunning natural beauty alongside persistent challenges. Situated on the western third of Hispaniola Island, it shares the island with the Dominican Republic. Haiti’s history is marked by colonialism, revolution, and significant socio-economic struggles, yet it possesses a vibrant culture, resilient people, and a unique biodiversity.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: The bustling capital and largest city of Haiti.
quickFacts.detail: Port-au-Prince is a major economic, political, and cultural center, though it faces significant infrastructure challenges.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: Haiti's population is diverse, with a significant Creole-speaking majority.
quickFacts.detail: The population density is high, particularly in urban areas.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.description: Haiti is a relatively small country with varied topography.
quickFacts.detail: It’s characterized by mountainous terrain, coastal plains, and a central plateau.

quickFacts.label: Official Language
quickFacts.description: French is used in government and education, while Haitian Creole is the most widely spoken language.
quickFacts.detail: Creole is a blend of French, African languages, and indigenous influences.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The Haitian Gourde is pegged to the US Dollar.
quickFacts.detail: Inflation has been a persistent issue in Haiti's economic history.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: Haiti has one of the lowest GDPs in the Western Hemisphere.
quickFacts.detail: The economy is heavily reliant on agriculture and remittances.

climateData.title: Tropical Climate
climateData.description: Haiti experiences a tropical climate with distinct wet and dry seasons. The mountainous terrain contributes to significant rainfall variations across the country.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Dry Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The dry season is generally sunny and relatively cool, particularly in the mountains.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Wet Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The wet season brings heavy rainfall, flooding, and landslides, especially in the lowlands.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Hurricane Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Haiti is vulnerable to hurricanes and tropical storms during this period.
activities: Limited outdoor activities during storm threats

naturalWonders.name: Citadelle Laferrière
naturalWonders.description: A UNESCO World Heritage site, the Citadelle is a massive mountaintop fortress built in the early 19th century. It stands as a symbol of Haitian independence and resilience.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The Citadelle is an impressive feat of engineering, constructed without mortar using locally sourced stone. Its strategic location and imposing presence made it a formidable defense against foreign invaders.
viewingTips: Hire a local guide for historical context
Wear sturdy shoes for the steep climb

naturalWonders.name: Cascades de Bassalette (Saline Waterfalls)
naturalWonders.description: A series of stunning waterfalls cascading down a cliff face into a natural pool, surrounded by lush vegetation. It's a popular swimming spot and a beautiful natural spectacle.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The Cascades de Bassalette are located in the northern mountains of Haiti. The water is exceptionally pure and salty, giving it a unique taste.
viewingTips: Wear appropriate footwear for the slippery rocks

naturalWonders.name: Pic Macaya
naturalWonders.description: The highest peak in Haiti, offering breathtaking panoramic views of the island.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: Reaching Pic Macaya is a challenging but rewarding hike. The summit provides a stunning vista of the surrounding mountains and valleys.
viewingTips: Bring plenty of water and snacks

ecosystemData.title: Haitian Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: Haiti’s ecosystems are remarkably diverse, ranging from coastal mangroves to cloud forests and mountainous highlands. However, they are increasingly threatened by deforestation, unsustainable agriculture, and climate change.

biodiversityCategories.name: Tropical Rainforest
biodiversityCategories.description: Dominates the mountainous regions, harboring a vast array of plant and animal species.

statistics.details: One of the most biodiverse regions in the Caribbean

notableSpecies.name: Haitian Parrot
notableSpecies.significance: A unique parrot species found only in Haiti

biodiversityCategories.name: Mangrove Forests
biodiversityCategories.description: Coastal wetlands providing crucial habitat for marine life and protecting shorelines from erosion.

statistics.details: Supports numerous fish and invertebrate species

activities.title: Outdoor Activities in Haiti
activities.description: Haiti offers a range of outdoor activities, from hiking and birdwatching to water sports and cultural experiences.

activityCategories.name: Hiking
activityCategories.description: Explore Haiti’s mountainous terrain and discover stunning landscapes.

activities.name: Citadelle Hike
activities.description: A challenging hike to the iconic Citadelle Laferrière.

activities.name: Pic Macaya Ascent
activities.description: A strenuous climb to the highest peak in Haiti.
activities.requirements: Hiking poles, appropriate clothing, plenty of water

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
activityCategories.description: Enjoy the Caribbean Sea with various water sports activities.

activities.name: Coastal Swimming
activities.description: Relax and swim in the warm waters of the Caribbean Sea.
